messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 64 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computationally efficient sparse clustering

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study statistical and computational limits of clustering when the means of the centres are sparse and their dimension is possibly much larger than the sample size. Our theoretical analysis focuses on the model Xi=zi‚ÄãŒ∏+Œµi,zi‚àà{‚àí1,1},Œµi‚àºùí©‚Äã(0,I)formulae-sequencesubscriptùëãùëñsubscriptùëßùëñùúÉsubscriptùúÄùëñformulae-sequencesubscriptùëßùëñ11‚àºsubscriptùúÄùëñùí©0ùêºX_{i}=z_{i}\theta+\varepsilon_{i},~{}z_{i}\in\{-1,1\},~{}\varepsilon_{i}\thicksim\mathcal{N}(0,I), which has two clusters with centres Œ∏ùúÉ\theta and ‚àíŒ∏ùúÉ-\theta. We provide a finite sample analysis of a new sparse clustering algorithm based on sparse PCA and show that it achieves the minimax optimal misclustering rate in the regime ‚ÄñŒ∏‚Äñ‚Üí‚àû‚ÜínormùúÉ\|\theta\|\rightarrow\infty. Our results require the sparsity to grow slower than the square root of the sample size. Using a recent framework for computational lower bounds‚Äîthe low-degree likelihood ratio‚Äîwe give evidence that this condition is necessary for any polynomial-time clustering algorithm to succeed below the BBP threshold. This complements existing evidence based on reductions and statistical query lower bounds. Compared to these existing results, we cover a wider set of parameter regimes and give a more precise understanding of the runtime required and the misclustering error achievable. Our results imply that a large class of tests based on low-degree polynomials fail to solve even the weak testing task.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 64 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 64"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "An ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù theory of PCA and spectral clustering",
        "Efficient sparse clustering of high-dimensional non-spherical gaussian mixtures",
        "Minimax theory for high-dimensional gaussian mixtures with sparse mean separation",
        "High-dimensional analysis of semidefinite relaxations for sparse principal components",
        "Average-Case Lower Bounds for Learning Sparse Mixtures, Robust Estimation and Semirandom Adversaries",
        "Optimal Average-Case Reductions to Sparse PCA: From Weak Assumptions to Strong Hardness",
        "Reducibility and statistical-computational gaps from secret leakage",
        "Reducibility and computational lower bounds for problems with planted sparse structure",
        "Phase transition of the largest eigenvalue for non-null complex sample covariance matrices",
        "Model-based clustering of high-dimensional data: A review",
        "A nearly tight sum-of-squares lower bound for the planted clique problem",
        "Statistical and computational tradeoffs in biclustering",
        "Slope meets Lasso: Improved oracle bounds and optimality",
        "Complexity theoretic lower bounds for sparse principal component detection",
        "Optimal detection of sparse principal components in high dimension",
        "Statistical guarantees for the EM algorithm: From population to sample-based analysis",
        "Computational and statistical boundaries for submatrix localization in a large noisy matrix",
        "CHIME: Clustering of high-dimensional gaussian mixtures with EM algorithm and its optimality",
        "A direct formulation of sparse PCA using semidefinite programming",
        "Statistical query lower bounds for robust estimation of high-dimensional gaussians and gaussian mixtures",
        "Subexponential-Time Algorithms for Sparse PCA",
        "Maximum likelihood from incomplete data via the EM algorithm (with discussion)",
        "Sparse PCA via covariance thresholding",
        "Statistical algorithms and a lower bound for detecting planted cliques",
        "Curse of heterogeneity: Computational barriers in sparse mixture models and phase retrieval",
        "Clustering objects on subsets of attributes",
        "Sparse CCA: Adaptive Estimation and Computational Barriers",
        "Mathematical Foundations of Infinite-Dimensional Statistical Methods",
        "Partial recovery bounds for clustering with the relaxed k-means",
        "Sparse principal component analysis via axis-aligned random projections",
        "The power of sum-of-squares for detecting hidden structures",
        "Probability Inequalities for Sums of Bounded Random Variables",
        "Statistical Inference and the Sum of Squares Method",
        "Tight bounds for learning a mixture of two Gaussians",
        "Efficient bayesian estimation from few samples: community detection and related problems",
        "A greedy anytime algorithm for sparse PCA",
        "Counterexamples to the low-degree conjecture",
        "Phase transitions for high dimensional clustering and related problems",
        "On Consistency and Sparsity for Principal Components Analysis in High Dimensions",
        "Influential features PCA for high-dimensional clustering",
        "Efficient noise-tolerant learning from statistical queries",
        "Do semidefinite relaxations solve sparse PCA up to the information limit?",
        "Notes on Computational Hardness of Hypothesis Testing: Predictions using the Low-Degree Likelihood Ratio",
        "Phase transitions and optimal algorithms in high-dimensional Gaussian mixture clustering",
        "Least squares quantization in PCM",
        "Minimax sparse principal subspace estimation in high dimensions",
        "Sparsistency and agnostic inference in sparse PCA",
        "Statistical and Computational Guarantees of Lloyd‚Äôs Algorithm and its Variants",
        "Sparse principal component analysis and iterative thresholding",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for sparse PCA",
        "Computational barriers in minimax submatrix detection",
        "Sharp optimal recovery in the two component gaussian mixture model",
        "Estimation of wasserstein distances in the spiked transport model",
        "Penalized model-based clustering with application to variable selection",
        "Approximating k-means-type clustering via semidefinite programming",
        "Lecture notes on high-dimensional statistics",
        "Detection and feature selection in sparse mixture models",
        "Fantope Projection and Selection: A near-optimal convex relaxation of Sparse PCA",
        "A tutorial on spectral clustering",
        "A spectral algorithm for learning mixture models",
        "Statistical and computational trade-offs in estimation of sparse principal components",
        "A framework for feature selection in clustering",
        "Variable selection for model-based high-dimensional clustering and its application to microarray data",
        "Randomly initialized EM algorithm for two-component Gaussian mixture achieves near optimality in O‚Äã(n)ùëÇùëõO(\\sqrt{n}) iterations"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 64 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computationally efficient sparse clustering, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
